body: Ariella L. Rosenberg and Matthew Brent Maron were married last evening at Stage Six at Steiner Studios, a complex for film production at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Rabbi Henry Weiner performed the ceremony. Mrs. Maron, 30, is a senior policy adviser on the sustainability of the City of New York to Daniel L. Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic
title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; Ariella Rosenberg, Matthew Maron

body: City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. issued an audit yesterday accusing the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation of keeping records poorly, having a flawed leasing system and failing to pay the city $2.2 million in rent. The audit, which covered the fiscal year that ended on June 30, 2004, said that the corporation had no written policies
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Navy Yard Agency Faulted

body: When the New-York Historical Society opened an extensive exploration of slavery in New York last year with an ambitious exhibition, it began to transform how New York remembers itself. The city, of course, always had its riots, its social traumas, its eruptions of unrest, but wasn't New York (at least in our cosmopolitan imaginations) immune from
title: EXHIBITION REVIEW; The Complex Legacy Of an Enslaved Past

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and a bevy of officials broke ground yesterday on the largest expansion program of the Brooklyn Navy Yard since World War II. The project is to bring 401,900 additional square feet of industrial space and a 60,000-square-foot supermarket to a complex that once housed Confederate prisoners of war and launched ships into
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Navy Yard Expansion Begins

body: The boat is called the Empty Vessel. The name was meant to conjure infinite possibility, a floating tabula rasa on the Gowanus Canal in the form of a 63-foot World War II Navy rescue craft. Fifteen months ago, the Empty Vessel journeyed up the canal on a mission both modest and, in this fenced-off, parceled-up city, almost unthinkably grand: to
title: GOWANUS JOURNAL; A Ship of Freethinkers, Hemmed In by Landlords

body: THE Brooklyn Navy Yard is in the early stages of a more than $100 million renovation, one its overseers hope will give a further boost to the long-neglected former shipbuilding site, which has bounced back in recent years and now has more than 200 tenants. Demolition is to begin early next year on Building 128, a former machine shop as big and
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN WATERFRONT; A Shipyard's Rebirth, Guided by the Past

body: AROUND 15 years ago, a decade after Sean Sweeney got out of the party-planning business and moved into a loft in the artists' haven and former industrial backwater called SoHo, he found himself the host of a meeting of a neighborhood group called the SoHo Alliance. The group's answering service, it turned out, had a severe backlog of unreturned
title: The Mini Mayors

body: DEAR DIARY: I run American Jewish World Service, an international relief and development organization that has been doing substantial work against the mass killings in Darfur. title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: ALEXANDER GORLIN, the SoHo architect known for work on Daniel Libeskind's TriBeCa apartment and the Congregation Orach Chaim synagogue on the Upper East Side, has also designed the latest installment of the Nehemiah Houses, along Jamaica Bay in Brooklyn. The developers of the Nehemiah Spring Creek Houses at Gateway Center -- row houses reserved for
title: POSTING; Affordable Houses Infused With Color

body: On the outside of the fence, it is 2006. On the inside, in many ways, it is still 2001. Yesterday, the World Trade Center Memorial Museum opened a bridge of memory between those worlds as it began mounting large photographs of 9/11, from prelude to aftermath, on the ground zero fence. No fireballs will be seen here. No blurred jetliners seconds
title: In Ground Zero Photo Exhibition, Worlds of 9/11 and Today Meet

body: Sweat darkened the brim of Nicholas Evans-Cato's straw hat last week as he brushed oil paint onto a six-foot-wide canvas, all the while perched on the tar-paper roof of an old factory building in Dumbo, Brooklyn. It was scorching hot up there, but Mr. Evans-Cato had no time to waste. In front of him was a half-finished painting of the Brooklyn
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DUMBO; Now You Paint 'Em, Now You Don't

body: Louis Winnick, an economist who played a major role in guiding the investments of the Ford Foundation in housing, community renewal and minority enterprise activity from the late 1960's through the 1980's, died yesterday at a hospice in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 85 and lived in Great Neck, N.Y. The cause of death was mesothelioma, a type of lung
title: Louis Winnick, Housing Expert, Dies at 85

body: To the Editor: The article about the Commandant's House at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, formally known as Quarters A, (Streetscapes, June 25) was of great interest to me because I was there in 1942. I was assigned to the commanding officer of the Eastern Sea frontier as chauffeur/bodyguard when the U.S.S. Missouri was christened. I drove Senator Harry
title: An Eyewitness Account

author: Edwin G. Burrows, a history professor at Brooklyn College and the co-author of "Gotham: A History of New York to 1898," is the author of the forthcoming ''The Prisoners of New York.''
body: NEW YORKERS are a famously restless, impatient sort of people, focused more on where they're going than where they've been. That's a real pity where the American Revolution is concerned, because the city played a key role in the resistance to King George III that led up to the Declaration of Independence. It's also the place where thousands of men
title: Devil's Island, New York

body: ON Tuesday, fireworks will explode above the East River to celebrate the 230th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence. But the American Revolution went on long past July 4, 1776 -- and a lot of it took place in New York City. In fact, if the very same fireworks show had taken place on the night of Aug. 29, 1776, the redcoats might have
title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK: REVOLUTIONARY WAR SITES; Where the Muskets Once Roared

body: The Streetscapes column last Sunday about the Commandant's House at the Brooklyn Navy Yard misstated the completion date for Gracie Mansion, another important house built in the same era. It was finished in 1799. (An addition to the mansion was completed in 1804.)
title: CORRECTION

author: E-mail: streetscapes@nytimes.com
body: IN a New York of secret delights, the Commandant's House at the Brooklyn Navy Yard is a secret secret. Built early in the 19th century, the big white house, formally known as Quarters A, is the yard's oldest surviving structure, with exquisite Federal-style detailing. In private ownership since the Navy Yard closed in 1964, the three-story house
title: STREETSCAPES/Commandant's House, Brooklyn; A Federal-Style Gem That Outshines Gracie Mansion

body: Having served as a military museum in New York City for almost 25 years, the U.S.S. Intrepid is due for some R and R -- in this case, that would be relocation and refurbishment. The Intrepid, a World War II-era aircraft carrier, has been a hulking fixture on the West Side of Manhattan since it first docked there in the early 1980's. But all that
title: 900-Foot Fixture on Hudson Is Set to Float Off for Repairs

body: WHEN you pass Reliable Naval Tailoring Co., an Army-Navy store on a forlorn waterfront block of Flushing Avenue in Brooklyn near the East River, you wonder whether it's still in business. The outward evidence -- a dust-coated storefront, outdated merchandise -- suggests that it closed sometime during the Carter administration. Yet the lights are
title: Urban Studies/Suiting Up; Nautical but Very Nice

body: THERE are fences along both sides of Jay Street on the block that is most visitors' first view of the Dumbo section of Brooklyn. One, backed up against the Manhattan Bridge just outside the F train stop, is ramshackle blue plywood, covered with photocopies of building permits and signs for construction companies. title: Side By Side

body: SWEET AND LOW A Family Story. By Rich Cohen. Illustrated. 272 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25. title: The Bitter Truth

body: ROSENTHAL--Albert. Humanitarian, educator, mentor, leader, influenced the lives of so many people. Loving and devoted husband of Mildred. Dear father of Ellen Rosenthal-Gelband and Barbara J. title: Paid Notice: Deaths ROSENTHAL, ALBERT

author: Andrew Rice last wrote for the magazine about George Weah, the Liberian presidential candidate. He is writing a book about Uganda.
body: Bernie Tetreault was driving along Good Hope Road, past the Baptist churches and check-cashing storefronts that populate Washington's poorest neighborhood, when a dented green street sign caught his eye. It marked the way to the Frederick Douglass Dwellings, a place that no longer existed. ''Yeah, those are gone,'' he said. ''That's Henson Ridge.''
title: Affordable Housing; The Suburban Solution

title: Silvercup Studios Sets $1 Billion Complex

body: New York City's Department of Environmental Protection admitted yesterday that its failure to maintain and repair backup generators at several sewage treatment plants violated environmental laws and caused the illegal discharge of 30 million gallons of untreated human waste into the East River during the 2003 blackout. As a result, a federal judge
title: Sewage Failure in Blackout Puts City Under Court's Thumb

body: ARTHUR MELNICK shifted gears on his boxy white Nissan, skirted past Fulton Ferry Landing and described his vision for the future of Brooklyn. ''Look at this!'' he said, pointing at the nearly desolate ribbon of Furman Street. Traffic on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway screamed overhead, and the old docks and industrial buildings along the East River
title: URBAN TACTICS; A Desire Named Streetcar

body: The largest room at Steiner Studios, the year-old moviemaking compound at the Brooklyn Navy Yard between Williamsburg and Fort Greene, is 27,000 square feet, with ceilings more than 45 feet high. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: URBAN STUDIES -- Filming; Next Subway Stop: Hollywood
